elements.content: A three-dimensional (3D) metal–organic framework (MOF) of [Et2NH2]2[Cd5(BTB)4(DEF)2]·4.75DEF (1; H3BTB = benzene-1,3,5-tribenzoic acid and DEF = N,N′-diethylformamide) sustained by symmetrical Z-shaped Cd5 secondary building units (SBUs) with an intrinsically metastable host framework has been prepared and characterized. Upon gentle vacuum (800 Pa) at 50 °C, some encapsulated DEF solvates are released, leading to pore-shape changes and Cd2+ coordination geometry distortion. This is followed by DEF solvate migration to only one end of the SBU with concomitant symmetry breaking. Additional time under vacuum promoted further structural distortion and topology changes as authenticated by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. This work was initially inspired by unusual gas adsorption isotherms and points to the potentially complicated, nonspectator role of coordinative solvents such as DEF during MOF activation.
elements.clean_text: A three-dimensional (3D) metal-organic framework (MOF) of [Et2NH2]2[Cd5(BTB)4(DEF)2]⋅4.75DEF (1; H3BTB = benzene-1,3,5-tribenzoic acid and DEF = N,N'-diethylformamide) sustained by symmetrical Z-shaped Cd5 secondary building units (SBUs) with an intrinsically metastable host framework has been prepared and characterized. Upon gentle vacuum (800 Pa) at 50 °C, some encapsulated DEF solvates are released, leading to pore-shape changes and Cd2+ coordination geometry distortion. This is followed by DEF solvate migration to only one end of the SBU with concomitant symmetry breaking. Additional time under vacuum promoted further structural distortion and topology changes as authenticated by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. This work was initially inspired by unusual gas adsorption isotherms and points to the potentially complicated, nonspectator role of coordinative solvents such as DEF during MOF activation.

elements.content: A three-dimensional (3D) metal−organic framework of [Et2NH2]2[Cd5(BTB)4(DEF)2]·4.75DEF (1; H3BTB = benzene-1,3,5-tribenzoic acid and DEF = N,N′-diethylformamide) sustained by symmetrical Z-shaped Cd5 secondary building units with an intrinsically metastable host framework has been prepared and characterized.
elements.clean_text: A three-dimensional (3D) metal-organic framework of [Et2NH2]2[Cd5(BTB)4(DEF)2]⋅4.75DEF (1; H3BTB = benzene-1,3,5-tribenzoic acid and DEF = N,N'-diethylformamide) sustained by symmetrical Z-shaped Cd5 secondary building units with an intrinsically metastable host framework has been prepared and characterized.

elements.content: Flexible metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are porous solids with highly ordered structures with intrinsically dynamic behavior. They exhibit bistable or multistable crystalline states with long-term structural order, reversible transitions between states, and permanent pores. Flexible MOFs are third-generation MOFs, or soft porous materials, according to Kitagawa et al. and are a class of superior and responsive materials that have found use in isotope separation, activation-dependent gas adsorption, and negative gas adsorption. One of the flexible behaviors of MOFs is characterized by the “breathing” process, referring to the reversible transition between open and closed pores with a dramatic change in the unit cell volume and pore volume in response to external stimuli (e.g., adsorption/desorption of the guest molecule). Occasionally, several distinctive intermediate states can be captured, as indicated by the hysteretic gas adsorption curves and authenticated by X-ray crystallography to provide structural snapshots of these intriguing transition states.
elements.clean_text: Flexible metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are porous solids with highly ordered structures with intrinsically dynamic behavior. They exhibit bistable or multistable crystalline states with long-term structural order, reversible transitions between states, and permanent pores. Flexible MOFs are third-generation MOFs, or soft porous materials, according to Kitagawa et al. and are a class of superior and responsive materials that have found use in isotope separation, activation-dependent gas adsorption, and negative gas adsorption. One of the flexible behaviors of MOFs is characterized by the "breathing" process, referring to the reversible transition between open and closed pores with a dramatic change in the unit cell volume and pore volume in response to external stimuli (e.g., adsorption/desorption of the guest molecule). Occasionally, several distinctive intermediate states can be captured, as indicated by the hysteretic gas adsorption curves and authenticated by X-ray crystallography to provide structural snapshots of these intriguing transition states.

elements.content: N,N′-Dimethylformamide (DMF) and N,N′-diethylformamide (DEF) are two of the most commonly used solvents for MOF syntheses. They are often retained in the pores of the as-synthesized MOFs. However, as coordinative ligands, their structural role upon subsequent MOF treatments, such as vacuum, heating, solvate exchange, metathesis, etc., is poorly understood, presumably because of the loss of single crystallinity that frequently accompanies these processes. Dincǎ et al. have elegantly described the dynamic binding of DMF in MOF-5 that facilitates metathesis with Co2+ due to an increase in the coordination number of Zn2+ to dynamically dissociate it from the framework.
elements.clean_text: N,N'-Dimethylformamide (DMF) and N,N'-diethylformamide (DEF) are two of the most commonly used solvents for MOF syntheses. They are often retained in the pores of the as-synthesized MOFs. However, as coordinative ligands, their structural role upon subsequent MOF treatments, such as vacuum, heating, solvate exchange, metathesis, etc., is poorly understood, presumably because of the loss of single crystallinity that frequently accompanies these processes. Dincǎ et al. have elegantly described the dynamic binding of DMF in MOF-5 that facilitates metathesis with Co2+ due to an increase in the coordination number of Zn2+ to dynamically dissociate it from the framework.

elements.content: “Breathing” MOFs are largely sustained by mononuclear, dinuclear, linear/trigonal-prismatic trinuclear cluster secondary building units (SBUs). In our previous work, we reported that the cationic three-dimensional (3D) MOF [Et2NH2]2[Cd5(BTB)4(DEF)2]·4.75DEF (1; H3BTB = benzene-1,3,5-tribenzoic acid) exhibited an intriguing “breathing” behavior during CO2 adsorption studies. MOF 1 featured a Z-shaped Cd5 cluster SBU wherein the central Cd2+ was coordinated by a pair of DEF solvate molecules (a). The overall SBU was symmetrical wherein the center-of-inversion coincided with the central Cd2+. The 3D structure of 1 also featured 1D channels with rhombic apertures that were filled with [Et2NH2]+ cations and free DEF solvates (a). The CO2 isotherms of MOF 1 demonstrated multistep adsorption with a desorption hysteresis (Figure S1). The adsorption curve partly resembles that of type F–II isotherms for flexible microporous materials (suddenly opening from small pores to larger pores). Replacing DEF solvates with CHCl3 resulted in a pore-shape change to compressed rhombic apertures but with retention of the MOF topology. Notably, the CO2 isotherms of the CHCl3-exchanged sample exhibit a standard type I adsorption with slight hysteresis, indicating that MOF 1 is a metastable phase and could readily transform into a more stable phase upon solvate exchange. It is also interesting to note that pore variation upon guest exchange also leads to significant geometry distortion of Cd2+, as evidenced by the additional coordination of 4-pyridinealdehyde and 4-acetylpyridine to the two flanked Cd2+ instead of the intended substitution of the coordinated DEF on the central Cd2+.

MOF 1 featured a Z-shaped Cd5 cluster SBU wherein the central Cd2+ was coordinated by a pair of DEF solvate molecules (a). The overall SBU was symmetrical wherein the center-of-inversion coincided with the central Cd2+. The 3D structure of 1 also featured 1D channels with rhombic apertures that were filled with [Et2NH2]+ cations and free DEF solvates (a). The CO2 isotherms of MOF 1 demonstrated multistep adsorption with a desorption hysteresis (Figure S1). Replacing DEF solvates with CHCl3 resulted in a pore-shape change to compressed rhombic apertures but with retention of the MOF topology. Notably, the CO2 isotherms of the CHCl3-exchanged sample exhibit a standard type I adsorption with slight hysteresis, indicating that MOF 1 is a metastable phase and could readily transform into a more stable phase upon solvate exchange. elements.content: Cd5 SBU of MOFs 1 (a), 1_10h (b), and 1_24h (c), showing the various DEF coordination patterns. All hydrogen atoms, free solvates, disordered domains, and guest-like [Et2NH2]+ are omitted, and only one phenylcarboxylate of each BTB ligand is shown for clarity. Color legend: cadmium, magenta; oxygen, light red; carbon, gray. The coordinated DEF molecules were distinguished with oxygen (red), nitrogen (blue), and carbon (black) for comparison purposes.

Color legend: cadmium, magenta; oxygen, light red; carbon, gray. The coordinated DEF molecules were distinguished with oxygen (red), nitrogen (blue), and carbon (black) for comparison purposes.

elements.content: Parallel view of the 3D extended structures of MOFs 1 (a), 1_5h (b), 1_10h (c), and 1_24h (d), showing the pore aperture changes. All hydrogen atoms, free solvates, disordered domains, and guest-like [Et2NH2]+ are omitted. Color legend: cadmium, magenta; oxygen, light red; nitrogen, light blue; carbon, gray.

elements.content: The above-mentioned CO2 isotherms suggest that the intrinsically metastable MOF 1 may undergo several distinctive and continuous phase changes under vacuum. Indeed, we were fortunate to isolate three additional phases in this process by using gentle vacuum (800 Pa) with mild heating (50 °C). Surprisingly, we found that the encapsulated DEF played a profound, nonspectator role in binding to only one end of the Cd5-based SBU, leading to SBU symmetry breaking and thus a bizarre structural conversion cascade.
elements.clean_text: The above-mentioned CO2 isotherms suggest that the intrinsically metastable MOF 1 may undergo several distinctive and continuous phase changes under vacuum. Indeed, we were fortunate to isolate three additional phases in this process by using gentle vacuum (800 Pa) with mild heating (50 °C). Surprisingly, we found that the encapsulated DEF played a profound, nonspectator role in binding to only one end of the Cd5-based SBU, leading to SBU symmetry breaking and thus a bizarre structural conversion cascade.

elements.content: Applying gentle vacuum (800 Pa) to the single crystals of MOF 1 at 50 °C for 5, 10, and 24 h gave rise to samples denoted as MOFs 1_5h, 1_10h, and 1_24h, respectively. The crystals retained their crystallinity during this process. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) of MOF 1_5h indicated a change in the pore shape to a more compressed rhombic relative to MOF 1 (a,b) without altering the scaffold connectivity or the coordination environment of the SBU. Applying vacuum for 10 h (MOF 1_10h) caused the guest DEF molecules to migrate to only one of the terminal Cd2+, leading to symmetry breaking of the Cd5 SBU (b). This is counterintuitive because the Cd5 SBU is symmetrical with a center-of-inversion that coincides with the central Cd2+. The terminal DEF can be refined as half-occupancy but not spatially disordered over the two flanked Cd2+. Meanwhile, the two DEF solvated on the central Cd2+ can also be refined to full occupancy, suggesting that the DEF may have originated from the encapsulated solvate molecules, and this solvent migration process was partial. We speculate that this bizarre SBU symmetry breaking under vacuum may arise from a complicated interplay between the metastable framework of MOF 1, the low symmetrical DEF, and the presence of the low-symmetry [Et2NH2]+. Notably, this SBU symmetry breaking results in the formation of two types of pores in MOF 1_10h (c and S2), with one rhombic aperture (right column) more compressed than the other (left column).
elements.clean_text: Applying gentle vacuum (800 Pa) to the single crystals of MOF 1 at 50 °C for 5, 10, and 24 h gave rise to samples denoted as MOFs 1_5h, 1_10h, and 1_24h, respectively. The crystals retained their crystallinity during this process. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) of MOF 1_5h indicated a change in the pore shape to a more compressed rhombic relative to MOF 1 (a,b) without altering the scaffold connectivity or the coordination environment of the SBU. Applying vacuum for 10 h (MOF 1_10h) caused the guest DEF molecules to migrate to only one of the terminal Cd2+, leading to symmetry breaking of the Cd5 SBU (b). This is counterintuitive because the Cd5 SBU is symmetrical with a center-of-inversion that coincides with the central Cd2+. The terminal DEF can be refined as half-occupancy but not spatially disordered over the two flanked Cd2+. Meanwhile, the two DEF solvated on the central Cd2+ can also be refined to full occupancy, suggesting that the DEF may have originated from the encapsulated solvate molecules, and this solvent migration process was partial. We speculate that this bizarre SBU symmetry breaking under vacuum may arise from a complicated interplay between the metastable framework of MOF 1, the low symmetrical DEF, and the presence of the low-symmetry [Et2NH2]+. Notably, this SBU symmetry breaking results in the formation of two types of pores in MOF 1_10h (c and S2), with one rhombic aperture (right column) more compressed than the other (left column).

elements.content: Surprisingly, we found that this terminally captured DEF has a high affinity toward Cd2+ and is retained upon further treatment under vacuum at 50 °C for 24 h (MOF 1_24h), at which point both of the DEF molecules on the central Cd2+ have evaporated. MOF 1_24h features a significant coordination reorientation of the BTB ligand on Cd2+ (c) and accordingly the 3D structure (d). Compared to that in MOF 1_10h, the DEF solvate on Cd2+ rotated to an approximately axial position on the Cd5 SBU as a result of the cooperative movement of all of the individual components, such as Cd2+, BTB ligand, DEF, and aqua molecules. As a result, each of the Cd2+ centers in the SBU has a different coordination pattern.
elements.clean_text: Surprisingly, we found that this terminally captured DEF has a high affinity toward Cd2+ and is retained upon further treatment under vacuum at 50 °C for 24 h (MOF 1_24h), at which point both of the DEF molecules on the central Cd2+ have evaporated. MOF 1_24h features a significant coordination reorientation of the BTB ligand on Cd2+ (c) and accordingly the 3D structure (d). Compared to that in MOF 1_10h, the DEF solvate on Cd2+ rotated to an approximately axial position on the Cd5 SBU as a result of the cooperative movement of all of the individual components, such as Cd2+, BTB ligand, DEF, and aqua molecules. As a result, each of the Cd2+ centers in the SBU has a different coordination pattern.

elements.content: The SCXRD data for MOFs 1, 1_5h, 1_10h, and 1_24h showed a progressive decrease of the cell volume from 4269.2(13) Å3 (1, Z = 1) to 3886.9(4) Å3 (1_5h, Z = 1) to 7609.3(10) Å3 (1_10h, Z′ = 2) to 6352.4(11) Å3 (1_24h, Z = 2) as well as significant variations of the coordination geometries around the five Cd2+ (Table S2). Accordingly, the solvent-accessible voids were also reduced under vacuum, from 1731.6 Å3 (40.6%) for MOF 1 to 944.1 Å3 (24.3%) for MOF 1_5h to 2208.5 Å3 (29.0%) for MOF 1_10h to 1147.0 Å3 (18.1%) for MOF 1_24h, as calculated using PLATON. The lower void percentage of MOF 1_5h (24.3%) relative to MOF 1_10h (29.0%) was due to the different refinement models used for [Et2NH]+. In MOF 1_5h, the two [Et2NH]+ cations were refined with the positional disorder that occupied more void spaces, while the two [Et2NH]+ cations in MOF 1_10h were ordered.
elements.clean_text: The SCXRD data for MOFs 1, 1_5h, 1_10h, and 1_24h showed a progressive decrease of the cell volume from 4269.2(13) Å3 (1, Z = 1) to 3886.9(4) Å3 (1_5h, Z = 1) to 7609.3(10) Å3 (1_10h, Z' = 2) to 6352.4(11) Å3 (1_24h, Z = 2) as well as significant variations of the coordination geometries around the five Cd2+ (Table S2). Accordingly, the solvent-accessible voids were also reduced under vacuum, from 1731.6 Å3 (40.6%) for MOF 1 to 944.1 Å3 (24.3%) for MOF 1_5h to 2208.5 Å3 (29.0%) for MOF 1_10h to 1147.0 Å3 (18.1%) for MOF 1_24h, as calculated using PLATON. The lower void percentage of MOF 1_5h (24.3%) relative to MOF 1_10h (29.0%) was due to the different refinement models used for [Et2NH]+. In MOF 1_5h, the two [Et2NH]+ cations were refined with the positional disorder that occupied more void spaces, while the two [Et2NH]+ cations in MOF 1_10h were ordered.

elements.content: The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of MOFs 1, 1_5h, 1_10h, and 1_24h indicated a marginal peak shift upon extension of the time under vacuum (). However, the bulk samples remained crystalline, and these experimental peaks were largely consistent with the simulated peaks (Figure S3). The experimental peaks did fully resemble those of the simulated spectrum due to the partially complete reaction or overreaction related to the size of these single crystallites, as well as the regional temperature differences during the reactions.
elements.clean_text: The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of MOFs 1, 1_5h, 1_10h, and 1_24h indicated a marginal peak shift upon extension of the time under vacuum (). However, the bulk samples remained crystalline, and these experimental peaks were largely consistent with the simulated peaks (Figure S3). The experimental peaks did fully resemble those of the simulated spectrum due to the partially complete reaction or overreaction related to the size of these single crystallites, as well as the regional temperature differences during the reactions.

elements.content: PXRD patterns of MOFs 1, 1_5h, 1_10h, and 1_24h showing variation of the diffraction peaks upon vacuum treatment.
elements.clean_text: 3  PXRD patterns of MOFs 1, 1_5h, 1_10h, and 1_24h showing variation of the diffraction peaks upon vacuum treatment.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) showed that MOF 1 is stable up to ca. 100 °C, followed by two major weight losses, characterized as 6.75 DEF (21.2%, calcd 21.8%) before 234 °C and 2 [Et2NH2]+ (4.7%, calcd 5.9%) in the range 234–330 °C (Figure S4a). This TGA profile was replicated in MOF 1_5h but with less weight loss (17.8%) before 234 °C (Figure S4b). This result indicates that for MOF 1_5h there was a small amount of DEF that escaped because of the pore-shape change. Careful inspection of the TGA curves for MOFs 1 and 1_5h also indicated that there was a weight loss shoulder at around 163 °C presumably because of the loss of both coordinated and encapsulated DEF. This change was more obvious in the TGA patterns of MOFs 1_10h and 1_24h, which exhibited limited solvate loss before ca. 163 °C as a result of prior extrusion of the uncoordinated DEF solvates (Figure S4c,d). A comparison of these TGA data indicated that the overall DEF content decreased significantly under extended vacuum, corroborating the trend of the SCXRD data.
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) showed that MOF 1 is stable up to ca. 100 °C, followed by two major weight losses, characterized as 6.75 DEF (21.2%, calcd 21.8%) before 234 °C and 2 [Et2NH2]+ (4.7%, calcd 5.9%) in the range 234-330 °C (Figure S4a). This TGA profile was replicated in MOF 1_5h but with less weight loss (17.8%) before 234 °C (Figure S4b). This result indicates that for MOF 1_5h there was a small amount of DEF that escaped because of the pore-shape change. Careful inspection of the TGA curves for MOFs 1 and 1_5h also indicated that there was a weight loss shoulder at around 163 °C presumably because of the loss of both coordinated and encapsulated DEF. This change was more obvious in the TGA patterns of MOFs 1_10h and 1_24h, which exhibited limited solvate loss before ca. 163 °C as a result of prior extrusion of the uncoordinated DEF solvates (Figure S4c,d). A comparison of these TGA data indicated that the overall DEF content decreased significantly under extended vacuum, corroborating the trend of the SCXRD data.

elements.content: It is notable that when the vacuum time was extended to 32 h, there was significant further structural change, as suggested by the PXRD patterns (Figure S5). However, this process was accompanied by crystallinity loss. After 32 h, the structure seemed stable, as was also evidenced by the PXRD patterns upon vacuum for 64 h. This might indicate that the DEF solvates had been completely extruded. It is also notable that when MOF 1_24h was reimmersed in DEF for 24 h, the sample became highly amorphous (Figure S6), although some PXRD peaks at the low angle resembled those of MOF 1. A more careful investigation is needed to validate this reversibility process.
elements.clean_text: It is notable that when the vacuum time was extended to 32 h, there was significant further structural change, as suggested by the PXRD patterns (Figure S5). However, this process was accompanied by crystallinity loss. After 32 h, the structure seemed stable, as was also evidenced by the PXRD patterns upon vacuum for 64 h. This might indicate that the DEF solvates had been completely extruded. It is also notable that when MOF 1_24h was reimmersed in DEF for 24 h, the sample became highly amorphous (Figure S6), although some PXRD peaks at the low angle resembled those of MOF 1. A more careful investigation is needed to validate this reversibility process.

elements.content: As a follow-up to our previous work on gas adsorption, we further measured the CO2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of two other phases: MOFs 1_4h and 1_32h with samples activated at room temperature (Figure S7). The isotherms of MOF 1_4h resemble those of MOF 1, while those of MOF 1_32h are different, although with similar gas uptake capacity. We examined the PXRD patterns of MOF 1 after gas adsorption. The results suggest that there is a significant structure distortion toward MOF 1_24h (Figure S8) presumably due to the extended equilibrium time under much lower pressure. Unfortunately, a crystal-clear understanding of the temperature and pressure contributions to the gas adsorption behaviors is a daunting task.
elements.clean_text: As a follow-up to our previous work on gas adsorption, we further measured the CO2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of two other phases: MOFs 1_4h and 1_32h with samples activated at room temperature (Figure S7). The isotherms of MOF 1_4h resemble those of MOF 1, while those of MOF 1_32h are different, although with similar gas uptake capacity. We examined the PXRD patterns of MOF 1 after gas adsorption. The results suggest that there is a significant structure distortion toward MOF 1_24h (Figure S8) presumably due to the extended equilibrium time under much lower pressure. Unfortunately, a crystal-clear understanding of the temperature and pressure contributions to the gas adsorption behaviors is a daunting task.

elements.content: In this preliminary work, we have reported a bizarre case of vacuum-induced consecutive structural transformations of a Cd5-based 3D MOF under mild heating conditions. The loss of symmetry of the large Cd5-based SBU is particularly noteworthy and is responsible for the subsequent connectivity changes within both the SBUs and MOFs. This rare symmetry reduction may arise from the complicated interplay between the metastable framework of MOF 1, the low symmetrical DEF, and the equally low symmetrical [Et2NH2]+. Several issues remain to be solved, for example, the identity of the precursor for MOF 1_24h before the two water molecules are involved, the structure of fully evacuated DEF solvates, etc. This work also serves as a reminder of the important and potentially complicated role of coordinated solvates such as DEF during MOF activation.
elements.clean_text: In this preliminary work, we have reported a bizarre case of vacuum-induced consecutive structural transformations of a Cd5-based 3D MOF under mild heating conditions. The loss of symmetry of the large Cd5-based SBU is particularly noteworthy and is responsible for the subsequent connectivity changes within both the SBUs and MOFs. This rare symmetry reduction may arise from the complicated interplay between the metastable framework of MOF 1, the low symmetrical DEF, and the equally low symmetrical [Et2NH2]+. Several issues remain to be solved, for example, the identity of the precursor for MOF 1_24h before the two water molecules are involved, the structure of fully evacuated DEF solvates, etc. This work also serves as a reminder of the important and potentially complicated role of coordinated solvates such as DEF during MOF activation.

cln_elements.content:
The SCXRD data for MOFs 1, 1_5h, 1_10h, and 1_24h showed a progressive decrease of the cell volume from 4269.2(13) Å3 (1, Z = 1) to 3886.9(4) Å3 (1_5h, Z = 1) to 7609.3(10) Å3 (1_10h, Z′ = 2) to 6352.4(11) Å3 (1_24h, Z = 2) as well as significant variations of the coordination geometries around the five Cd2+ (Table S2). Accordingly, the solvent-accessible voids were also reduced under vacuum, from 1731.6 Å3 (40.6%) for MOF 1 to 944.1 Å3 (24.3%) for MOF 1_5h to 2208.5 Å3 (29.0%) for MOF 1_10h to 1147.0 Å3 (18.1%) for MOF 1_24h, as calculated using PLATON. The lower void percentage of MOF 1_5h (24.3%) relative to MOF 1_10h (29.0%) was due to the different refinement models used for [Et2NH]+. In MOF 1_5h, the two [Et2NH]+ cations were refined with the positional disorder that occupied more void spaces, while the two [Et2NH]+ cations in MOF 1_10h were ordered.

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) showed that MOF 1 is stable up to ca. 100 °C, followed by two major weight losses, characterized as 6.75 DEF (21.2%, calcd 21.8%) before 234 °C and 2 [Et2NH2]+ (4.7%, calcd 5.9%) in the range 234–330 °C (Figure S4a). This TGA profile was replicated in MOF 1_5h but with less weight loss (17.8%) before 234 °C (Figure S4b). This result indicates that for MOF 1_5h there was a small amount of DEF that escaped because of the pore-shape change. Careful inspection of the TGA curves for MOFs 1 and 1_5h also indicated that there was a weight loss shoulder at around 163 °C presumably because of the loss of both coordinated and encapsulated DEF. This change was more obvious in the TGA patterns of MOFs 1_10h and 1_24h, which exhibited limited solvate loss before ca. 163 °C as a result of prior extrusion of the uncoordinated DEF solvates (Figure S4c,d). A comparison of these TGA data indicated that the overall DEF content decreased significantly under extended vacuum, corroborating the trend of the SCXRD data.

The SCXRD data for MOFs 1, 1_5h, 1_10h, and 1_24h showed a progressive decrease of the cell volume from 4269.2(13) Å3 (1, Z = 1) to 3886.9(4) Å3 (1_5h, Z = 1) to 7609.3(10) Å3 (1_10h, Z' = 2) to 6352.4(11) Å3 (1_24h, Z = 2) as well as significant variations of the coordination geometries around the five Cd2+ (Table S2). Accordingly, the solvent-accessible voids were also reduced under vacuum, from 1731.6 Å3 (40.6%) for MOF 1 to 944.1 Å3 (24.3%) for MOF 1_5h to 2208.5 Å3 (29.0%) for MOF 1_10h to 1147.0 Å3 (18.1%) for MOF 1_24h, as calculated using PLATON. The lower void percentage of MOF 1_5h (24.3%) relative to MOF 1_10h (29.0%) was due to the different refinement models used for [Et2NH]+. In MOF 1_5h, the two [Et2NH]+ cations were refined with the positional disorder that occupied more void spaces, while the two [Et2NH]+ cations in MOF 1_10h were ordered.

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) showed that MOF 1 is stable up to ca. 100 °C, followed by two major weight losses, characterized as 6.75 DEF (21.2%, calcd 21.8%) before 234 °C and 2 [Et2NH2]+ (4.7%, calcd 5.9%) in the range 234-330 °C (Figure S4a). This TGA profile was replicated in MOF 1_5h but with less weight loss (17.8%) before 234 °C (Figure S4b). This result indicates that for MOF 1_5h there was a small amount of DEF that escaped because of the pore-shape change. Careful inspection of the TGA curves for MOFs 1 and 1_5h also indicated that there was a weight loss shoulder at around 163 °C presumably because of the loss of both coordinated and encapsulated DEF. This change was more obvious in the TGA patterns of MOFs 1_10h and 1_24h, which exhibited limited solvate loss before ca. 163 °C as a result of prior extrusion of the uncoordinated DEF solvates (Figure S4c,d). A comparison of these TGA data indicated that the overall DEF content decreased significantly under extended vacuum, corroborating the trend of the SCXRD data.

decomposition temperature.type: gradual removal of coordinated water molecules
